instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP3V0_G3H: What is PP3V0_G3H? PP3V0_G3H is a 3.0v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no turning on
threads.message:
Hi,

It is my first post. I follow you from Spain, excuse my english faults. I'm not advaved in electronics but I'm leraning a lot.

The board received a wine splash. It was ultrasonic cleaned.
No visible damage in lcd connector.
No fan spinning.
Gets 20.3v but 0 amps

Working:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH5V</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH3V3</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S4_HS_TPAD</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_SMC_ISNS</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>


Not working:

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
PPVCCPRIMCORE_SUS_PCH
<SIGNAL>PP1V0_SUS</SIGNAL>

etc.

Regards from Spain!

Marcos

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no turning on
threads.message:
Bienvenidos Marcos.

Exact value for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?
Can you describe the areas affected by liquid spill?

Do you get <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> high level?
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check if <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no turning on
threads.message:
Gracias!

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 13.13v

I do not know the affected areas.


<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>: 3.37V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> :0V
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts when <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> (<RESISTOR>R5226</RESISTOR>) is triggered.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no turning on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no turning on
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> :0V"
Should stay always at high level.
If not, PCH system management block is kept in reset mode...

It is controlled by <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.
If you have <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, check <RESISTOR>R7810</RESISTOR> integrity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no turning on
threads.message:
Hi again,

<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> Ws ok, cheked and replaced <RESISTOR>R7810</RESISTOR>. Now power is just 5.20v 0amps

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no turning on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no turning on
threads.message:
You still have corrosion problem.
Supposedly under some BGA chips; maybe SMC, or USB-C controllers.
But can be <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, or CPU.
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> goes high in some moment?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no turning on
threads.message:
supposedly <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> and <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> were reballed in a tech support store.
I noticed <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_TB</SIGNAL> is not working.

<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> goes high in some moment? no
